abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Sector Development Program
            (RSDP) Project involves the rehabilitation of roads
            following existing alignments, thus, it is expected that
            environmental impacts will be minimal. Nevertheless, this
            environmental assessment reviews the legal, and
            administrative framework in Ghana, and the alternatives
            examined for improvement of existing roads. It specifies
            that clearing around the right-of-way, or for borrow pits
            may threaten ecosystems, such as forests, wetlands and
            wildlife refuges; construction works may lead to
            sedimentation, and pollution of streams, and water bodies,
            resulting from the operation of heavy machinery; potential
            erosion, and inadequate drainage would increase water
            pollution levels; and, air, and noise pollution, as a result
            of construction, and increased traffic, may affect roadside
            communities, in terms of health and safety problems.
            Mitigation include: 1) installation of culverts to prevent
            water logging, and an immediate vegetative propagation, will
            minimize soil erosion, and sedimentation; 2) drainage
            discharges will be appropriately located to control, and
            manage solid wastes, fuel and oil spills, and sewage to
            prevent water pollution; 3) likewise, groundwater leakage,
            and pollution of water resources will be adequately
            discharged, in accordance with sanitary measures; 4) a
            buffer zone will be maintained to protect, and preserve
            local flora and fauna; and, 5) spraying, and surface covers
            will minimize dust pollution; vehicle maintenance and
            regular working schedules would reduce noise disturbances;
            and, traffic safety include the installation of traffic
            signs, and provision of alternate route diversions.
